poem:
Corrections and Clarifications  

The editor's gentle broom sweeps  
the stage of ink, where names  
blur like evening headlights.  
A single letter misplaced,  
a director misattributed—  
yet beneath these minor stumbles,  
a world spins on, oblivious.  
In the margins, truth kneels  
to adjust its spectacles,  
quietly setting the record  
straight for tomorrow's eyes.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • The Score is directed by Trevor Nunn, not Brian Cox as our interview with the latter said (‘I can be quite a loudmouth …’, 7 December, Saturday magazine, p14). And Richard Eyre was artistic director of the National Theatre from 1988 to 1997, not 1987 to 1999 (Obsession with stars is block to making films, says Eyre, 30 November, p19). • An article said research from 25 studies had “revealed that recreational and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
